key_points: Joe Biden honored US troops killed in the Kabul airport attack during a dignified transfer ceremony at Dover Air Force Base.
Biden and First Lady Jill Biden attended the ceremony for the 13 members of the US military killed.
The ceremony took place under criticism of Biden's handling of the exit from Afghanistan.
Defense Secretary Lloyd Austin and Secretary of State Antony Blinken, among other dignitaries, joined Biden at the ceremony.
Biden called the fallen soldiers "heroes" in a speech on Hurricane Ida and expressed the personal pain of loss, recalling his late son Beau.
The Kabul airport attack killed more than 100 Afghans and is blamed on a regional arm of the Islamic State.
The US launched drone strikes on Islamic State targets following the attack.
Biden faces criticism over the chaotic US withdrawal from Afghanistan, with approximately 250 US nationals remaining in Afghanistan.
National Security Advisor Jake Sullivan assured those remaining they "are not going to be stuck in Afghanistan."
